summary: ISA is a significant disease of farmed Atlantic salmon (Salmo salar L.) it was first identified in Norway in 1984. it is caused by a negative-sense, segmented single-stranded RNA (ssRNA) virus in the Orthomyxoviridae family (37) ISA is a relatively novel disease with poorly understood pathogenesis. symptoms include severe anemia and hemorrhagic liver necrosis. other common findings include increased hemophagocytosis, ascites, petechia. the viral attachment protein for orthomyxoviruses, the hemagglutinin (HA), attaches to sialic acid-containing receptors. this tropism is determined by the distribution of Neu4,5Ac (4-O-acetylated sialic acids), the preferred receptor for the virus (20. cells were washed twice in ice-cold L-15 and scraped off using cell scrapers. IHC revealed strong positive ISAV staining confined to the endothelial layer of all types of vessels in all organs, including capillaries, veins, and arteries. the location of stained ISAV in the endothelial cells was sometimes confined only to the nucleus but most frequently present in the cytoplasm. anti-ISAV HE and anti-ISAV NP antibodies revealed abundant virus antigen associated with the surface of most RBCs. it appears that ISAV produced by vessel endothelium attaches to the surface but does not infect or replicate within the RBCs. Tissue samples from experiments 2 and 3 and cytospin preparations from experiment 2 were examined by IHC. the cytospin preparations showed approximately 0.1% of the leukocytes positive for ISAV antigen at day 2 p.i., with no positive staining observed in endothelial cells in tissue sections at this time point. lymphocyte depletion was observed in experiment 2 by differential counting. all organs investigated contained large amounts of ISAV confined to endothelial cells of the vasculature. however, in the hemorrhagic, coagulative necrosis in liver and kidney, no ISAV was detected by IHC. in situ hemadsorption was observed in some cases, as was in situ RBC agglutination. ISAV pattern of virus attachment largely explains endotheliotropism in salmon. endothelial cells and RBCs are the main virus target cells during ISAV infection. the ISAV receptor was found on endothelial cells and on RBCs. IFAT labeling of blood smears with anti-ISAV HE and anti-ISAV NP antibodies revealed abundant virus antigen associated with the surface of most RBCs. no expression of viral proteins was detected in either the cytoplasm or the nucleus of RBCs. ISAV infection is detected in leukocytes and gill epithelium. cytospin preparations showed 0.1% of the leukocytes positive for ISAV antigen at day 2 p.i., with no positive staining observed in endothelial cells in tissue sections at this time point. the results indicate that there may be a primary replication stage in gill epithelial cells and in leukocytes. results from experimental infections do not always correlate with natural infections. infected endothelial cells (red) were detected adjacent to hemorrhagic liver necrosis (HCN) (CV, central vein) (a) and tubular necrosis (TN) in kidney (b). endothelial cells and RBCs are main virus target cells during ISAV infection. we did not find any changes in the distribution, suggesting that infected endothelium was intact. nor did we find any indications that the receptor was more or less abundant in tissues from ISAV-infected fish. serum from either horse or guinea pig, either of which predominantly contains 4-O-acetylated sialic acids, blocked the reaction while no inhibition was observed with native rat, pig, or cattle serum. the combined data of this work and those presented by Helleb et al. (20) suggest that ISAV HE binds to 4-O-acetylated sialic acids. IFAT staining of uninfected heart shows greater presence of ISAV receptor at the luminal side (arrows) of endothelial cells. ISA is characterized by severe anemia and circulatory disturbances. gill epithelial infection could be sufficient to establish the systemic infection that appeared similar regardless of immersion or i.p. challenge. however, the level of gill epithelial infection was low, and this opens the possibility that other infection routes are important. early endothelial infection and viremia are key events during systemic influenza virus infection in several birds (25, 49) and have also been demonstrated in cats (40, 42). stressed endothelium alters its permeability function and can express molecules which may promote recruitment of inflammatory cells. several viruses have coevolved with bony fishes, including paramyxoviruses and orthomyxoviruses. some key functional activities characteristic of orthomyxoviruses have been retained through evolution. similarities between ISA pathogenesis in Atlantic salmon and systemic phase of influenza virus infection in domestic poultry.
